The house was not easily disposed of, and the little money which their father had left them was hardly sufficient for their immediate wants. Their two eldest sons were settled in life, and though, from inclination and affection, they might have been expected to do a great deal, they could do nothing. Edward Ferrars, indeed, would have parted from his profession, and settled near them, could he have supposed it would be any assistance; but the little independence which his mother's fortune and his own moderate income secured, made it unnecessary. He had been able to save a considerable sum by living economically in a cheap situation, and this he meant to endeavour to augment, that he might be able to assist all the family in time; but of immediate service he could do none. The two younger Miss Dashwoods were also provided for; they were gone to school, and were doing well. The only remaining object of anxiety or care was their mother, whose strength was daily failing, and whose spirits seemed wholly broken by change and sorrow. She was no longer able to direct or superintend in anything; her daughters were therefore as unsettled and uncomfortable as ever, and the removal was delayed from day to day. At length, however, it was resolved to quit Norland, and the plan was this: Edward Ferrars was to take a small house in the city, and invite his mother to live with him; and Mrs. Dashwood, with her three daughters, was to rent a cottage in Sussex, about thirty miles from Edward's abode, where they would have country air, cheap living, and constant society with him. This arrangement was not displeasing to Mrs. Ferrars, who considered it as a final separation of the families, which she much wished for, and was only prevented by her son's affection for his sister's family from proposing it herself. She was fond of city life and indifferent to the country, and would rather see Edward established in town, though at a very moderate expense, than residing in the country as a gentleman of large income. The house in town was taken, the removal was happily effected, and the cottage in Sussex engaged, with many mutual promises of frequent visits and long letters, when the separation, which had seemed so final, began to wear a more tolerable aspect. Mrs. Dashwood was not the woman to be long depressed by any change of circumstances, and soon began to feel the true value of independence. She accepted the cottage with all the advantage of enthusiasm, and looked forward to the enjoyment of a private parsonage with rapture. Her spirits and health rapidly improved; she was no longer the prey of sorrow, anxiety, and discontent. She began to taste the pleasure of hope once more, and found, as she had always expected, that it was by no means impossible to be comfortable on a small income and in a small way. Her daughters were growing up; they were healthy, clever, and good-humoured girls, of a pretty equal age, with a comfortable home before them, and only required education and society to complete their happiness. The two eldest were sent to a small school near home, which Mrs. Jennings recommended very highly, and where they made excellent progress for a few months; and the youngest, who was only just four years old, to a nursery governess, who lived in the village and came every day to the cottage. The term was short, and the arrangement well calculated to give the children ease and pleasure. It is a weakness too often falling to the lot of those who are most disposed to think well of others, and who, from an excess of good nature, are ready to receive the first opinion that offers, without weighing its justness. In my case, I believe, this disposition to err in estimating characters is heightened by my own natural temper, which is rather cool and collected than sanguine and presumptuous. I am not of those who rush into admiration at the first glimpse of a stranger, or who, from a single brilliant action or saying, are ready to pronounce a man or woman a prodigy of wit or virtue. I like to look around me, to understand the scene, to observe the characters with whom I am to deal, and to form my opinions with caution. This method, while it may prevent some hasty errors, also sometimes leads to a slowness of judgment that might be avoided. In the present instance, however, I am confident that a little more acquaintance with Marianne will convince you that my judgment is not at fault. Her disposition is so different from what I had imagined it to be; her powers of reasoning so little cultivated, her understanding so desultory and uncertain, that I am surprised at my own mistake.
